sections.heading: PROJECT DEFINITION
sections.text: A primary motivation for the use of wireless sensor networks is the detection of changes over large ranges, which could be a change in the environment, such as the temperature of the atmosphere or the presence of a property in the received signal that differs from what was previously received. It is an anomaly that is much more difficult than traditional detection, where we know the signal we wish to detect. Many methods for detecting anomalies have been proposed, and the method being investigated in this project is based on estimating the entropy of a signal directly from the data. Entropy itself is estimated by first estimating the probability density function using the k-next neighbor (k-NN) technique, which is applied to actual measured data. 1) The pre-dissertation phase includes a literature survey on the use of anomalies within wireless sensor networks, as well as the preparation of a Matlab simulation of suitable test signals.

sections.heading: ABSTRACT
sections.text: Anomalies are strange data points; they usually represent an unusual occurrence. Anomaly detection is presented from the perspective of wireless sensor networks. Various approaches have been taken in the past, as we will see, not only to identify outliers, but also to establish the statistical properties of the various methods.The usual goal is to show that the approach is asymptotically efficient and that the metric used is impartial or possibly biased. This project is based on a paper by [1]. The approach is based on the principle that the entropy of the data is increased when an anomalous data point is measured. The entropy of the data set is therefore impartial or possibly biased. However, this report presents preliminary efforts to confirm the results of [1]. To estimate the entropy of the data set, since no parametric form is assumed, the probability density function of the data set is unpredictable.

sections.text: Anomaly in wireless sensor networks has been studied very intensively [6], although the approach comes from different directions and application areas. sections.heading: 2.3 Theory
sections.text: Anomalous detection methods are usually based on modifying a property of the data or system that is monitored to function effectively. Many methods rely in one way or another on the probability distribution function of the data [1] [14], usually in combination with another property. This project represents, as already mentioned, an anomaly detection method based on the change (increase) in entropy that occurs when anomalous data is collected as shown in [1]. It works based on the fact that outliers are further away than any other data point in the dataset. This distance calculation is krux. This method does not assume any specific form for the measured data and so the pdf of the data is calculated first. sections.heading: 2.4 The Algorithm
sections.text: The k-next neighbor algorithm for estimating the entropy of a dataset follows [1] without assuming a specific shape for the data to be analysed.1. Capture data point. 2. Process the data in advance to eliminate the effects of thermal variations.3. specify k, the number of closest neighbors to be used, depending on the estimated number of suspicious fanomalies in the datasets.4. Calculate the distance of each data point to its closest neighbors. 5. estimate the pdf of the data. 6. estimate entropy. 7. set a threshold, which depends on the desired confidence interval and false alarm rate.123.0 PRACTICAL WORK

sections.heading: 4.1 Project Plan and Future Work
sections.text: So far, the project has progressed as follows; the literature review presented in this report and preliminary simulations carried out for the k-nn method using synthetic data (zero means Gaussian random variable with variance 4) are also presented in this report. The next phase of the report includes: 1. Evaluation of the k-nn technique on the test signals and comparison of the result with the closed form solution for the Gaussian random variable. 2. Detection of anomalies at previously known points. 3. Verification of the technique on the real data. 4. Improvement of the algorithm. 5. Writing of the theories.
